perturbation.original_text: The Company hereby engages the Contractor as an independent contractor and the Contractor hereby agrees to such engagement.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company hereby engages the Contractor as a worker and the Contractor hereby agrees to such engagement.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'independent contractor' to 'worker' creates ambiguity. While the contract intends to establish an independent contractor relationship, using the term 'worker,' which can be interpreted under employment law as an employee, contradicts this intention and introduces uncertainty. This contradiction can affect tax obligations, liability, and other legal aspects of the relationship.

perturbation.original_text: 3.3 Deductions and Remittances. Emerald shall not be obliged to deduct or retain from the Fees due to the Contractor, nor shall it be obliged to remit same to the required governmental authority, any amounts that may be required by law or regulation to be deducted, retained and remitted including, without limitation, Federal and Provincial or State Income Tax, Workers' Compensation and Pension Plan deductions and remittances. All such remittances and other payments are entirely the responsibility of the Contractor and the Contractor hereby indemnifies and saves Emerald and its Board members and officers harmless from any liability of any kind whatsoever that they may incur as a result of the Contractor's failure to make such remittances or payments.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.3 Deductions and Remittances. Emerald may choose whether or not to deduct or retain from the Fees due to the Contractor, any amounts that may be required by law or regulation to be deducted, retained and remitted including, without limitation, Federal and Provincial or State Income Tax, Workers' Compensation and Pension Plan deductions and remittances. All such remittances and other payments are the responsibility of the Contractor unless otherwise agreed upon and Emerald is not liable for contractor's remittances of payments.
perturbation.explanation: This alteration makes the deduction and remittance of taxes and other statutory payments discretionary, contradicting Canadian tax laws and regulations. The original clause clearly states that Emerald is not obliged to deduct, retain, or remit these amounts. The modified clause gives Emerald the option, creating confusion about who is responsible for remitting these deductions. This conflicts with the statutory obligations under the Income Tax Act and Employment Insurance Act, where employers may be required to deduct and remit certain amounts, even for independent contractors in some cases.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Income Tax Act (Canada), Employment Insurance Act (Canada)

perturbation.original_text: (d) "Cause" includes, without limitation, the following: (i) the Contractor's commission of any act of gross negligence or gross incompetence in the conduct of his or her Services, or in the performance of his or her obligations under this Agreement; (ii) a material breach or default of any term of this Agreement by the Contractor if such material breach or default has not been remedied within 60 days after written notice of the material breach or default has been delivered by the Company to the Contractor; (iii) the Contractor dying or becoming permanently disabled or disabled (which includes, without limitation, mental infirmary or mental illness, drug or alcohol abuse or impairment, or any other physical or mental impairment that materially interferes with the individual's ability to perform his or her Duties) for a period exceeding 180 consecutive days or 180 days calculated on a cumulative basis over any two-year period during the term of this Agreement; or (iv) the Contractor's fraud, dishonesty or other material misconduct, wilful or otherwise, including, without limitation, the Contractor being: (A) convicted of a criminal offence involving fraud or dishonesty; or (B) sanctioned by a corporate registry, stock exchange, securities commission or other similar regulatory organization in respect of a material breach of corporate, commercial or securities rules, policies, laws or regulations.
perturbation.changed_text: (d) "Cause" includes, without limitation, the following: (i) the Contractor's commission of any act of simple negligence in the conduct of his or her Services, or in the performance of his or her obligations under this Agreement; (ii) any breach or default of any term of this Agreement by the Contractor if such breach or default has not been remedied within 10 days after written notice of the breach or default has been delivered by the Company to the Contractor; (iii) the Contractor being unable to perform his or her duties to their best ability for more than 30 consecutive days; or (iv) the Contractor's misconduct, including, without limitation, the Contractor being: (A) suspected of a criminal offence involving fraud or dishonesty; or (B) questioned by a corporate registry, stock exchange, securities commission or other similar regulatory organization in respect of a breach of corporate, commercial or securities rules, policies, laws or regulations.
perturbation.explanation: The definition of 'Cause' for termination has been broadened to include 'simple negligence' instead of 'gross negligence or gross incompetence', 'any breach' instead of 'material breach', a shorter disability period (30 days instead of 180 days), and 'suspected of a criminal offence' instead of 'convicted'. This creates a contradiction as it allows the company to terminate the contract more easily and for less serious reasons than initially defined. This conflicts with common law principles that require a significant breach to justify contract termination, increasing the risk of wrongful termination claims. It also reduces the standard of proof required for termination.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Common Law Principles of Contract Termination
